dataset.title: SSU rRNA amplicon of the Arctic Ocean during Winter-Spring Transition

creator.organizationName: CIIMAR - Interdisciplinary Centre of Marine and Environmental Research

metadataProvider.organizationName: CIIMAR - Interdisciplinary Centre of Marine and Environmental Research

abstract.para: One of the main concerns about the Arctic Ocean has been the changing sea ice regime with a reduction in the summer sea ice extent and a shift in dominance from thicker, perennial multiyear ice towards thinner, first-year ice. As the dietary basis of marine food webs and central players of biogeochemical cycles, microbial communities play an irreplaceable role when evaluating the ecological impact of the Arctics thinner ice regime. During the Norwegian young sea Ice cruise 2015 (N-ICE2015), that took place in drifting pack ice north of Svalbard between January-June 2015, seawater was collected, at 5, 20 or 50, 250 m depth in 9th March, 27th April and 16th June, together with physical and biogeochemical data. Through the massively parallel sequencing of SSU rRNA amplicon we expect to get a snapshot of the Arctics microbiota diversity and structure through the dark-light transition.

intellectualRights.para: This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution (CC-BY) 4.0 License.

contact.organizationName: CIIMAR - Interdisciplinary Centre of Marine and Environmental Research

samplingDescription.para: One of the main concerns about the Arctic Ocean has been the changing sea ice regime with a reduction in the summer sea ice extent and a shift in dominance from thicker, perennial multiyear ice towards thinner, first-year ice. As the dietary basis of marine food webs and central players of biogeochemical cycles, microbial communities play an irreplaceable role when evaluating the ecological impact of the Arctics thinner ice regime. During the Norwegian young sea Ice cruise 2015 (N-ICE2015), that took place in drifting pack ice north of Svalbard between January-June 2015, seawater was collected, at 5, 20 or 50, 250 m depth in 9th March, 27th April and 16th June, together with physical and biogeochemical data. Through the massively parallel sequencing of SSU rRNA amplicon we expect to get a snapshot of the Arctics microbiota diversity and structure through the dark-light transition.

project.title: SSU rRNA amplicon of the Arctic Ocean during Winter-Spring Transition

gbif.citation: MGnify (2020). SSU rRNA amplicon of the Arctic Ocean during Winter-Spring Transition. Sampling event dataset https://doi.org/10.15468/v46e2k accessed via GBIF.org on 2023-04-13.

bibliography.citation: de Sousa AGG, Tomasino MP, Duarte P, Fernández-Méndez M, Assmy P, Ribeiro H, Surkont J, Leite RB, Pereira-Leal JB, Torgo L, Magalhães C. 2019. Diversity and Composition of Pelagic Prokaryotic and Protist Communities in a Thin Arctic Sea-Ice Regime. Microb Ecol vol. 78
